content:
Hi, I am a CS undergrad student. I completed all foundation parts of computer science courses . For Rust, I only finished reading the 20 chapters Rust book, and played around a little. I want to contribute to the community via proving some codings. I am looking for some larger group coding experience and coding on Rust experience. Do you guys have any recommendation for which group should I look at? I did look into the easy label Rust issues, which mostly are claimed or doc issues right now.
I can spent time to dig deep into certain topic, where it needs more help right now. But since I am only a undergrad student, I can not be an expert in a short period. I do not know which group should I look for.
Thank you for all replies in advance.
What kinds of interests do you have? There are many projects out there that need help, and I think you'll most enjoy and be productive contributing to a project that aligns with your interests.
Also, @Bart Massey is a CS professor and tends to have an endless supply of interesting projects. :)

Josh Triplett said:

What kinds of interests do you have? There are many projects out there that need help, and I think you'll most enjoy and be productive contributing to a project that aligns with your interests.

Sorry I didn't know I was not replying.

Not reading assembly code and not front end related will fit my interest. I have learned compiler(scanner, parser, scheduling, allocation, optiomzation ... ) a little while ago but not intermediate in anyway. I do not know if this level is enough to help the compiler people. I am looking for some projects that are active with maybe 5 or more people? Just want to learn how people cooperate in a larger open source project.
Rust itself has many issue marked a E-Easy
You can look through them and if one interests you, claim it and try to fix it :slight_smile:
e-mentoring is a nice label too, with people to help you if you have questions
If you have a tool/library you really like you can search for a rust version/rust bindings to it and try to contribute to it :slight_smile:

Poliorcetics said:

Rust itself has many issue marked a E-Easy

I have been searching for Easy issue, most of them are claimed already. I have been looking for a new easy issue in couple days now. I will continue check it out.
Not all issues are marked as easy, even when they could be so don’t hesitate to look for other issues, there are many interesting ones
Don’t be afraid to try too, people are very helpful and even when I did something wrong when trying to fix an issue, I’ve never felt as if I was blamed for it
You will get code reviews with lots of comments to guide you at worst

5M1Sec :

Sorry to be so slow responding. As @Josh Triplett suggested, I could probably find some interesting not-Rust-compiler things to do. Actually, I do have one libs project lying around: I've done some performance improvements to the integer pow() functions that need to be macroized and benchmarked and tested a bit better and then PRed upstream. LMK if you want to work on it and I'll get you hooked up with the code.
